The role of primary care in bowel cancer screening
subChapters.htmlHeader: What is the role of primary care in bowel cancer screening?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The delivery of the NHS Bowel Cancer Screening Programme does not directly involve primary care — GPs are informed when screening invitations are sent out in their area, sent copies of the results of screening and informed if there is no response to an invitation. Primary care can support the bowel screening programme by:

  • Promoting uptake of screening — provide information on the screening process and the need for repeat screening when invited. Patient information, posters and leaflets are available:
    • For the Bowel Screening Programme in England from:
      • Cancer Research UK "Bowel cancer screening. The facts"
      • Cancer Research UK “Screening in England, Wales and Northern Ireland”
      • Bowel Cancer UK "Bowel health and the home test kit. The NHS Bowel Cancer Screening Programme for people who are 60 years old and over"
      • Bowel Cancer UK "Checking your bowel is healthy. The NHS bowel scope test for people who are 55 years old"
      • The NHS "Overview. Bowel cancer screening”
    • For the Bowel Screening Programme in Scotland from:
      • Cancer Research UK “Bowel Cancer. Screening in Scotland”
      • Bowel Cancer UK "Bowel health and screening: carers guide. A booklet for carers of people who use easy read materials"
      • NHS Inform "Bowel screening"
      • NHS Inform "The bowel screening test: what you need to know”
    • For the Bowel Screening Programme in Wales from:
      • Bowel Screening Wales "Bowel screening Wales. Information for carers"
      • Bowel Screening Wales "Bowel screening explained. What you need to know about the bowel screening programme in Wales"
      • Cancer Research UK “Screening in England, Wales and Northern Ireland”
    • For the Bowel Screening Programme in Northern Ireland from:
      • HSCNI "Bowel cancer screening: the facts"
      • Cancer Research UK “Screening in England, Wales and Northern Ireland”
  • Ensuring that participants are aware that many but not all bowel cancers will be picked up through screening.
    • Provide information on the key signs and symptoms of bowel cancer (such as blood in stools, changes in bowel habit and abdominal pain) — advice the person to seek urgent medical review if symptoms develop even if they have taken part in screening recently.
    • Negative screening results should not be used to guide investigation of a person presenting with symptoms of bowel cancer.
      • There are major differences in the use of faecal occult blood testing in investigation of symptomatic disease compared to use as a screening test including different threshold levels for abnormal results — appropriate referral through the 2 week cancer wait is required.
      • For further information see the CKS topic on Gastrointestinal tract (lower) cancers - recognition and referral.
  • Advising the person on reducing the risk of bowel cancer by:
    • Participation in bowel screening when offered.
    • Maintenance of a healthy weight.
    • Eating a diet high in non-starchy vegetables, fruit, pulses, and whole grains, keeping red meat consumption to a minimum and avoiding processed meat.
    • Avoidance of alcohol or keeping consumption to within recommended limits.
    • Avoidance of smoking.
    • Regular physical activity (at least moderate intensity for a minimum of 30 minutes five days a week).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the contribution of primary care to the bowel screening programme are based on clinical guidance The UK NSC recommendation on bowel cancer screening in adults [UK NSC, 2016], Diagnosis and management of colorectal cancer. A national clinical guideline [SIGN, 2016], Scottish Bowel Screening Programme - a guide for professionals [NHS Health Scotland, 2017], Engaging primary care in bowel screening. GP good practice guide for Wales [Cancer Research UK, 2018], Engaging primary care in bowel screening. GP good practice guide for England [Cancer Research UK, 2019e] and Engaging primary care in bowel screening. GP good practice guide for Scotland [Cancer Research UK, 2019c].

Promote screening
  • Uptake of bowel screening is lower than that of other screening programmes. Primary care teams can promote uptake by raising awareness of the benefits of bowel screening and encouraging informed participation [NHS Health Scotland, 2017; Cancer Research UK, 2019e].
    • In Scotland, bowel screening uptake is lowest in 50–54 year olds, those from areas of high deprivation, and men [NHS Health Scotland, 2017].
    • In England bowel screening uptake is approximately 59% (lower in deprived areas). A pilot of the new faecal immunochemical test (FIT) reported an increase in uptake of about 7% — increased uptake was most marked in men. An increase in uptake was noted across all deprivation groups [Cancer Research UK, 2019e].
Screening is not 100% effective
  • Clinical guidance [SIGN, 2016; UK NSC, 2016] emphasises the importance of informing participants in bowel screening that no screening test is 100% effective. Some cancers may be diagnosed in the two-year interval between a negative bowel screening test and the next invitation (interval cancer) [NHS Health Scotland, 2017; Bowel Screening Wales, 2019b].
  • Clinicians should not be over-reassured by previous normal screening results.
    • One meta-analysis (n=29 studies) looking at the incidence of faecal occult blood test interval cancers in population-based colorectal cancer screening found that pooled incidence rates of interval colorectal cancer (iCRC) following FIT and gFOBT were 20 (95% CI 14–29) and 34 (95% CI 20–57) per 100 000 person years, respectively. In studies that included FIT results (n=17), the median faecal haemoglobin positivity cut-off used was 20 (range 10–200) µg Hb/g faeces [Wieten, 2019].
  • Clinicians should be aware that there are major differences in the use of FIT in investigation of symptomatic disease compared to use as a screening test such as different threshold levels for abnormal results [Cancer Research UK, 2019e].
Advice on reducing the risk of bowel cancer
  • Guidance from the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network Diagnosis and management of colorectal cancer. A national clinical guideline [SIGN, 2016] and Scottish Bowel Screening Programme - a guide for professionals [NHS Health Scotland, 2017] recommends education on lifestyle measures to lower risk of bowel cancer.
